docs.text: Welcome to the index for Array and Hashing problems! This section covers foundational concepts like two-pointer techniques, sliding windows, and hash map optimization.

docs.title: Key Concepts in Array Solutions
docs.text:
• Two Pointers: Optimizing algorithms that involve scanning through a list or array.
  • Sliding Window: Used for problems requiring contiguous subarrays (often for finding max/min length or sum).
  • Hash Maps (Dictionaries): Essential for $O(1)$ lookup time to improve time complexity from $O(n^2)$ to $O(n)$.

docs.title: 💡 Quick Link: Two Sum (ID: 1)
docs.text: This problem is solved using a Hash Map (dictionary) to store numbers and their indices. By iterating through the array once, we check if the complement (target - current_number) is already in the map.

docs.title: Complexity
docs.text:
• Time: $O(n)$ - A single pass over the array.
  • Space: $O(n)$ - Required space for the hash map in the worst case.

docs.title: 📝 Problem Statement
docs.text:
Given an array of integers nums and an integer target, return indices of the two numbers such that they add up to target.

You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice. You can return the answer in any order.

docs.title: 🧠 Approach: Hash Map (One-Pass)
docs.text: The most efficient solution avoids the $O(n^2)$ brute force method by leveraging a Hash Map (Python dict) for $O(1)$ lookups.

docs.title: The Core Idea: Searching for the Complement
docs.text:
Instead of searching the rest of the array for the second number, we determine the complement required for the current number to hit the target.

  1. We iterate through the array once.
  2. At each element num, we calculate: complement = target - num.
  3. We check if this complement already exists in our num_map (our dictionary).
    • If found: We have our two numbers! We return the stored index of the complement and the current index.
    • If not found: We store the current number and its index in the map for future lookups.
